gw.api.database

Class DBFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.database.DBFunction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IQueryColumn

    public abstract class DBFunction
extends java.lang.Object
implements IQueryColumn
    A set of static methods used to wrap a column in a SQL function

      • Constant

        public static DBFunction Constant(java.lang.String value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. For example:

        var q = Query.make(Person) q.compareIgnoreCase("LastName", Equals, DBFunction.Constant("Smith"))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        public static DBFunction Constant(java.lang.Number value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This can be used to compare a constant value against something in SQL in a having clause. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(2), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        public static DBFunction Constant(IDataType dataType,
                                  java.lang.Object value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version allows for an arbitrary datatype. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(DataTypes.bit(), false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        dataType - the datatype of the constant value
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • Constant

        public static DBFunction Constant(java.lang.Object value)
        Returns a constant wrapped so that it can be used in SQL whenever you want a literal parameter.

        This is typically used to compare a constant value against something in SQL. This version automatically utilizes datatype based on the type of the value. For example:

        var q = new Query(TestE) var aTable = q.join(TestA, "E") q.having().compare(DBFunction.Constant(false), Equals, DBFunction.Count( aTable.getColumnRef( "A" ) ))

        Parameters:
        value - the constant value to search on
        Returns:
        the constant value

      • DateDiff

        public static DBFunction DateDiff(DateDiffPart dateDiffPart,
                                  ColumnRef startDate,
                                  ColumnRef endDate)
        Parameters:
        dateDiffPart - Unit of measure for date difference
        startDate - Starting date time
        endDate - Ending date time
        Returns:
        a function that computes the difference between two datetime columns. The answer is returned in a unit of measure determined by the first argument. Note that database difference functions do not adjust for daylight savings time. For example, if you ask for the number of hours between noon on 11/5/11 and noon on 11/6/11, you will get 24 back, even though 25 hours has elapsed.

      • DatePart

        public static DBFunction DatePart(DatePart datePart,
                                  ColumnRef date)
        Parameters:
        datePart - Part of date to be extracted
        date - Date being processed
        Returns:
        a function that extracts the specified date part from the date.

      • DateFromTimestamp

        public static DBFunction DateFromTimestamp(ColumnRef timestamp)
        Parameters:
        timestamp - Timestamp to be trimmed to a date
        Returns:
        a function taht extracts just the date from the given timestamp

      • Distance

        public static DBFunction Distance(Query query,
                                  java.lang.String beanPath)
        Parameters:
        query - The query containing the spatial search restriction
        Returns:
        the distance function. Only valid if the query has a proximity search, otherwise fails in unpredictable ways.

      • Expr

        public static DBFunction Expr(java.lang.Object... expr)
        Returns a function defined by the given expression. The expression is a list containing either CharSequences or ColumnRefs. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. ColumnRef column1 = ... ColumnRef column2 = ... DBFunction columnSum = DBFunction.Expr({column1, " + ", column2}) Note that single quotes are stripped. To include a single quote in the pattern string use two single quotes.

        The user is advised to prefer the use of a ColumnRef for a column over a CharSequence because a ColumnRef encapsulates the table alias.

        Parameters:
        expr - objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression.
        Returns:
        a function defined by the given expression

      • Count

        public static DBFunction Count(ColumnRef column)
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the count value for the given column
